journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Effect of interlayer slip on the damping of layered and welded aluminium beams

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, India

author-notes.corresp: Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Jagda, Rourkela 769008, India. email: bhagatmech@gmail.com

abstract.p: Damping is a complex phenomenon, which acts in the form of absorption and dissipation of energy in the vibrating systems. Joints are inherently present in all most all assembled structures that contribute significantly to the slip damping. The joints fabricated by welding contribute to the damping mechanism in assembled structures. In this study, the relationship between the dynamic slip and damping capacity has been theoretically investigated considering the higher modes of vibration of the welded aluminium cantilever beams. The damping ratios of these structures are determined using forced vibration test method. It has been confirmed through the comparison of theoretical and experimental results that the damping capacity of a jointed cantilever beams can be well estimated using the proposed method.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Many structures that find wide applications in aerospace and automotive industries are assembled by welded connections. Usually, such structures possess low structural damping, necessitating incorporation of additional measures to improve their damping characteristics. One of the techniques used for this purpose is fabricating these structures in layers by means of joints, which provide adequate means of energy dissipation. Aluminium being lighter is one of the potential materials for such structures and it becomes imperative to understand the damping mechanism and quantify the same for successful design of the assembled structures in order to enhance their useful life. This has become important in the present global scenario because of continuous research and heavy investments in those industries.

An important feature of built-up structures is the existence of many mechanical joints that connect structural components, which lead to the existence of slip interfaces. Welded joints are such fasteners and have a great potential for reducing the vibration levels of fabricated structures. In such cases, when the dynamic load is increased or decreased within a threshold range, slip along the frictional joint interfaces occurs locally at the joints. This situation is called micro-slip, where slip along the interface is localized in the slip region while the rest of the interface is in the stick region. When the vertical load reaches beyond the threshold range, slip along the entire interfaces takes place which is being referred as macro-slip. While both micro and macro-slips cause energy dissipation providing the dominant damping mechanism in a built-up structure, the latter is generally avoided as it leads to structural damage of the joints. On the other hand, micro-slip provides a good level of energy dissipation without causing damage to the joints. Damping due to micro-slip is generally promoted in structural joint designs as it plays an important role in reducing the amplitude of structural vibrations, thereby increasing the fatigue life of the structures.

The mechanism of damping in assembled structures has received considerable interest by various investigators. Friction damping at slip interfaces has been the subject of many studies and is still a subject of current investigation [1–3]. In an earlier attempt, the theory of structural damping in a built-up beam has been investigated by Goodman and Klumpp [4] considering two identical beams pressed together with uniform pressure, forming a composite cantilever beam. When the beam was loaded with shear force at the free end, frictional slip was induced at the interfaces, causing energy dissipation. They developed a formula for determining the amount of energy dissipation per loading cycle under plane stress conditions.

Pian [5] considered a cantilever beam with reinforcing spar caps subjected to a vertical shear load at the free end. The reinforcing caps have been attached to the beam by rivets, generating pressure along the beam–spar interfaces. The sliding motion between the cap and the beam has been resisted by pressure-dependent friction at the interfaces. The damping behaviour of the built-up beam in bending has been investigated analytically in terms of an elastic beam theory. Energy loss per cycle of static loading has been evaluated and compared with experimental measurements.

Another classical work has been carried out by Metherell and Diller [6]; they investigated the damping behaviour of a lap-shear joint subjected to a uniform clamping pressure. The authors derived expressions for the load–deflection relationship, the energy dissipation per cycle, and the instantaneous rate of energy dissipation.

The early studies of frictional slip, energy loss, and damping properties of built-up structures with mechanical joints have been reviewed vividly by Goodman [7] and Ungar [8]. Following the work of Goodman [7], researchers such as Masuko et al. [9], Nishiwaki et al. [10], and Motosh [11] studied the damping capacity of layered and jointed structures assuming uniform intensity of pressure distribution at the interfaces. However, their work is limited to the layered and jointed structures with static loads.

Further, Masuko et al. [9], Nanda and Behera [12] examined the interfacial slip damping in layered bolted structures and developed a theoretical expression for the pressure distribution at the interfaces of a bolted joint by curve fitting the earlier data reported by Ziada and Abd [13]. They further extended their work by developing a generalized mathematical expression for the logarithmic damping decrement of such structures with multiple interfaces. Nanda and Behera [14, 15] and Nanda [16] further studied the distribution pattern of the interface pressure as well as the damping capacity of layered and jointed structures by carrying out numerical analysis and performed experiments to ascertain the effects of number of layers, diameter of bolts, and use of washers on the damping characteristics. However, their study is limited to the static loading without considering the effect of in-plane bending stresses on the dynamic slip and damping capacity.

The effect of non-uniform interface pressure distribution on the mechanism of slip damping for layered beams has also been examined recently by Damisa etal. [17], limiting their analysis to static loads and linear profiles of interface pressure distribution. However, Olunloyo et al. [18] have considered other forms of interfacial pressure distributions such as polynomial and hyperbolic and observed large difference in the results compared to the work of Damisa etal. [17]. Although all these researchers considered the in-plane distribution of bending stresses but their analysis is limited to the structures subjected to static loads.

Although a lot of work has been carried out on the damping capacity of bolted and riveted structures, but a little amount of work has been reported on the mechanism of damping in layered and jointed welded structures. The study of slip damping in welded structures is very vital for achieving maximum vibration attenuation in automotive and aerospace industries, where these structures are extensively used. Masuko et al. [9] and Nishiwaki et al. [10] have established that the welded steel structures can be used in machine tool structures as a substitute for monolithic cast iron material to compensate for damping. The use of welded steel structures furtherbecomes economical in saving the materials for heavy machine tools. Aoki [19] studied the effect of welding on dynamic characteristics of welded cantilever beam structures and established that the damping ratio increases when welding is used for the fabrication of the structures.

More recent works in this area include Vitelleschi and Schmidt [20] considering the effects of surface finish, Beards and Williams [21] on rotational slip, Jezequel [22] on a plate-theory analysis, Groper [23] on micro- and macro-slips in bolted joints, Wettergren [24] and Csaba [25] on the role of micro-slip in generating damping and reducing the dynamic instability of turbine generators.

In this study, attempt has been made to investigate the mechanism of slip damping in layered and welded aluminium beams. The mathematical analysis has been carried out, considering the in-plane bending stresses, which has been neglected by the earlier researchers. The analysis carried out by the earlier researchers is limited to the structures subjected to static loads. In this study, dynamic analysis has been done to investigate the effect of various types of loading on the slip damping of welded structures. The study of slip damping of welded structures is very vital for automotive and aerospace industries, where the jointed welded structures are predominantly used. The present investigation focuses on the influence of interface pressure distribution, relative dynamic slip, and kinematic coefficient of friction on the damping capacity of welded aluminium cantilever beams subjected to dynamic conditions. The energy approach of evaluation of loss factor has been presented to study the effect of various parameters on the damping capacity of such structures. Moreover, extensive experiments have been conducted on a number of specimens to authenticate the numerical results.

sec.title: 2.1 Static analysis
sec.p:
The two-layered and tack-welded cantilever beam model with overall thickness 2h, width b, and lengthl, as shown in Fig. 1(a) is considered to find out the damping capacity. The loading consists of uniformly distributed pressure at the interfaces due to the contact between two flat bodies, and a concentrated static load P is applied at the free end, x = l. Each of the two halves of thickness h is considered separately with the loading, as depicted in Fig. 1(b). The continuity of stress and vertical displacement v is imposed at the interfaces. At some finite value of P, the shear stress at the interfaces will reach the critical value for slip τxy=μp, where µ and p are the kinematic co-efficient friction and interface pressure, respectively. Additional force due to excitation will produce a relative displacement Δu(x) at the interfaces. Fig. 1
(a) Two layered tack welded cantilever beam model and (b) two halves of the beam depicting load and co-ordinates

sec.title: 2.1.1 Interface pressure distribution
sec.p: In the present analysis, the welded beams are considered to be in contact with each other because of perfect flatness and same condition of flatness is maintained under excitation due to welding. Since perfect contact is maintained under both the static and dynamic conditions, the pressure at the interfaces is assumed to be uniform. The contact pressure for flat surfaces with rounded corners has been found out by Ciavarella et al. [26], which shows a non-uniform distribution pattern at the interfaces. Contrary to this, the pressure distribution at the interfaces of flat surfaces is uniform owing to the contact of the upper layer over the lower one, as established byJohnson [27] and Giannakopoulos et al. [28]. Therefore, the pressure distribution due to contact of two flat bodies, as given by Johnson [27] and Giannakopoulos et al. [28], has been considered and the same is given by (1) where P and b are the normal load per unit length and width of the beam, respectively.

sec.title: 2.1.2 Analysis of static response
sec.p: The resultant moment at the centroid of each laminate, as shown in Fig. 1(b), is given by (2) where the subscripts 1 and 2 refer to the upper andlower laminates, respectively.
Invoking the relation between bending momentand curvature, as derived by Warburton [29], one gets (3) where E is the modulus of elasticity.
Substituting expression (3) in (2, the following expression is obtained (4) where I=bh3/bh312 12 is the moment of inertia of the cross-section of the beam.
Integrating expression (4) once, one gets (5) where C1 is the integration constant and evaluated tobe zero substituting the boundary condition, (dv/dvdx dx)|x=0=0, in expression (5).
Further, integration of expression (5) yields (6) where the integration constant, C2=0 since v|x=0=0.

Substituting the value of C2 in expression (6) and simplifying, the static deflection mode shape expression is given by (7) The two-dimensional (2D) parameters Q and R are defined as presented below (8a) (8b) Substituting expressions (8a) and (8b in (7) and simplifying, one gets (9)

sec.title: 2.1.3 Evaluation of relative slip
sec.p: The displacement at any axial position x and y1,2=∓h/2 are given by (10a) (10b) These displacements are produced by the resultant axial force F1,2 and moment M1,2, about the centroid of each half of the beam, as shown in Fig. 1(b).
Here, v1, v2 are the vertical deflections, E the modulus of elasticity, and σx1,σx2 the in-plane bending stresses. It is assumed that the continuity equation prevails, i.e. v1=v2=v.

From the equilibrium of force, the in-plane bending stresses in the upper and lower laminates are computed as follows (11a) (11b) Combining expressions (9) to (11) and simplifying, the relative slip displacement at the interfaces is given by (12) Slip will occur only if P>Pc=4Q/4Q3 3.
Here, Pc is the critical static load applied at the tip of the welded cantilever beams.

sec.title: 2.2 Dynamic analysis
sec.p: For the forced vibration of a cantilever beam, the static analysis has been extended to include distributed inertia forces and examine their effect on the mode shape, slip distribution, and energy dissipation due to slip. The analysis developed here follows the static analysis developed in the preceding sections for the beam, as shown in Fig. 1.

sec.title: 2.2.1 Analysis of dynamic response
sec.p: The forced vibration of the beam produced by a time-dependent displacement at the unsupported end has been considered such that (13) Following Timoshenko [30], the dynamic displacement is composed of two parts (14) where (15) The term in the bracket represents the static mode function and satisfies the end conditions (16) but not the dynamic equilibrium equation (17) where EI and ρ are the flexural rigidity and density ofthe beam, respectively.
The displacement vI produces the dynamic loads as given by (18) where A is the cross-sectional area of the beam.
Moreover, the displacement (vII)representing vibrations produced by the force function (18) is expressed as (19) where Xi(x) and φi(t) are the modal and time-dependent functions, respectively.

vII must satisfy the end conditions as follows (20) Xi(x) are the solutions of expression (17) and satisfies the end condition (20). Thus, one gets (21) where ki are the roots of the following expression (22) The total displacement is then given by (23) Applying the principle of virtual work, Timoshenko [30] has shown that the time-dependent functions φi(t) must satisfy the differential equation (24) where the superscript dots denote differentiation with respect to time. The coefficients bi are obtained by expanding the force function (18) in a series of the normal functions, Xi. Thus (25) and the coefficients bi are obtained from the following expression (26) Integrating expression (26), bi is finally given by (27) The general solution of expression (24) is given by (28) where pi=(EIAρ)1/12 2ki 2 Constants Ai and Bi are evaluated from the initial conditions (29a) (29b) Substituting expression (23) in expression (29), U and V are given by (30a) (30b) Moreover (31) Substituting expression (31) in (30) and simplifying, one gets (32a) (32b) Substituting the initial conditions U = V = 0, the constants Ai and Bi are evaluated as (33a) (33b) Substitution of expressions (28) and (33) in (23) yields (34) Integrating and simplifying expression (34), the transverse deflection is finally found to be (35)

sec.title: 2.2.2 Evaluation of dynamic slip
sec.p: The relative slip at the interfaces under dynamic condition is evaluated by combining expressions (10), (11), and (35). The relative slip at the interfaces is given by (36) Utilizing the expression for mode shape as given by (35) in (36), the relative slip is modified as (37)

sec.title: 2.2.3 Analysis of energy dissipated
sec.p: The energy is dissipated due to friction and relative dynamic slip at the interfaces. For completely reversed loading, the product of the shear force, μp and the relative displacement, Δu integrated over the length of the beam, which is found to be equal to one-fourth of the energy dissipated in a complete cycle.

Thus, energy dissipation per cycle, as established by Goodman and Klumpp [4], is given by (38) where u1 and u2 are the displacements in the x-direction of points on the adjacent faces of the upper and lower half beams, respectively.

Substituting expression (37) in (38), the energy dissipation per cycle is given by (39) Rearranging expression (39), one gets (40) Modifying expression (40), one has (41) Integrating expression (41), one gets (42) Simplifying expression (42), one gets (43) Rearranging expression (43), one gets (44) Expression (44) is modified substituting 2D parameters Q and R as given by expressions (8a) and (8b) and the same is given as (45)

sec.title: 2.2.4 Evaluation of loss factor
sec.p: In vibration problems, it is most convenient to express the dissipative properties of the system in terms of non-dimensional quantities such as the damping ratio ψ and loss factor ηs, defined by (46a) (46b) where Ene is the maximum strain energy stored in the system.

The maximum strain energy stored in the system in terms of dynamic deflection at the tip of the beam is given by (47) Substituting expressions (40) and (42) in expression (41a) and simplifying, the damping ratio in terms of dynamic tip displacement is given by (48) Substituting expression (43) in expression (41b) and simplifying, the loss factor in terms of dynamic tip displacement is given as (49) This result clearly indicates that the value for expression (44) cannot be fully determined until the forcing time-dependent displacement function f(t) is specified. Consequently, we limit our analysis to the following cases namely
where H(t) is the Heaviside function and F0 the amplitude
where ω is the excitation frequency.
The dynamic response, slip, and the loss factor have been evaluated for the above two cases of f(t) substituting expressions (50a) and (50b) in (35), (37), and (49).

sec.title: 3.1 Preparation of tack-welded aluminium specimens
sec.p:
The specimens are prepared from the stock of aluminium flats by tack welding two layers of various thicknesses and cantilever lengths. The details of the aluminium specimens used for experimentation are given in Table 1. The welding of aluminium flats has met with great difficulties because of its ability to oxidation. The moment it is prepared and cleansed, the aluminium at once covered with aluminium oxide, which prevents the pieces from fusing together. Using a flux, however, the oxidation skin is dissolved, and a dross is simultaneously formed, which enables the metal to flow and make a perfect weld. The commercial aluminium welding method has been employed which uses an electric arc with a permanent tungsten electrode plus filler wire (with AC current). The arc has been protected by argon gas (or argon–helium gas mix) to shield the weld pool and the electrode from the surrounding atmosphere. Arc welding is easy to use and regulate; also, it attains a high temperature and provides high heat input. To ensure an acceptable weld quality, two basic factors have been considered – breaking loose and removing the oxide film, and preventing the formation of new oxide during the weld process. It is essential that proper preparations and precautions are to be undertaken before welding commences. The surfaces to be joined and the area around the weld zone have been degreased using a solvent (acetone or toluene) and a clean cloth. The area has been cleaned and completely dried as grease and moisture can form gases and cause pores in the welded joint. The metal surface has been lightly brushed in and around the weld, after degreasing, to remove surface oxides and avoid oxide inclusion in the weld. The high melting temperature (~2000 °C) surface oxides has been removed just prior to welding (at least within 3 h or less). The weld has been properly shielded with the inert gas at the correct flow rate, and of the required purity. Care has been taken that the nozzle distance does not vary from the weld point. Table 1
Details of aluminium specimens used for layered and jointed beams
Thickness of the specimen (mm) Width of the specimen (mm) Number of layers Cantilever length (mm) Type of welding
3 40.2 2 520.6 Tack weld
4 40.2
5 40.2
6 40.2
3 40.2 2 560.4 Tack weld

sec.title: 3.2 Experimentation
sec.p:
An experimental set-up, as shown in Fig. 2, has been fabricated to conduct the experiments. The cantilever specimens are excited transversally by a time-dependent displacement at the free end with the aid of vibration generator. The input excitation and output vibration are sensed with vibration pick-ups and the corresponding signal is fed to a digital storage oscilloscope which is connected to the computer with vibration analyser software, i.e. Lab View of National Instruments Limited. Fig. 2
Experimental set-up

The frequency response has been measured for the first four modes of the vibration. Frequency response functions (FRFs) were measured in the frequency interval of 400 Hz with a resolution of 0.5 Hz. The frequency response curves at different loadings are plotted on a logarithmic scale, as shown in Figs 3 and 4. The experimental loss factor is then evaluated using experimental FRF curves. Fig. 3
FRF plot at harmonic loading for jointed and welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 600.6 × 40.2 × 3 mm3 Fig. 4
FRF plot at Heaviside loading for jointed and welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 600.6 × 40.2 × 3 mm3

sec.title: 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p:
The dynamic slip and transverse response of two-layered and tack-welded aluminium specimens have been found out numerically using expressions (35) and (37). From the analysis, following inferencesare drawn as outlined below. The variation of dynamic slip and transverse response at different locations along the cantilever beam length at various excitation frequencies for Heaviside and harmonic loading have been plotted in Figs 5 to 8, respectively. It is evident from the figures that the transverse response of vibration and the complementary interfacial slip increase with higher frequency ratio in the pre-resonance regime on one hand and behave conversely in the post-resonance zone. Moreover, the dynamic response and relative slip increases in the pre-resonance region with the increasing frequency and is maximum at the frequency ratio of one, i.e. at the resonant frequency. Fig. 5
Normalized slip profile at Heaviside loading with respect to the frequency ratio: (a) surface plot and (b) contour plot Fig. 6
Normalized slip profile at harmonic loading with respect to the frequency ratio: (a) surface plot and (b) contour plot Fig. 7
Normalized dynamic response at Heaviside loading with respect to the frequency ratio: (a)surface plot and (b) contour plot Fig. 8
Normalized dynamic response at harmonic loading with respect to the frequency ratio: (a)surface plot and (b) contour plot

The variation of energy dissipation with the initial amplitude of excitation for the layered and jointed beams of single interface has been plotted in Fig. 9. From the figure, it is apparent that the energy dissipation increases with the increase in initial amplitude of excitation. From expression (45), it is deduced that the energy loss due to friction is directly proportional to the initial amplitude of excitation, which establishes that the energy dissipation is enhanced with increase in initial amplitude of excitation. Further, the relative slip at the interfaces is increased due to increase in initial amplitude of excitation, as shown in expression (37), thereby enhancing the energy loss due to friction. The effect of relative slip due to dynamic loading on the energy loss is linearly proportional as the second term in the relative slip expression (37) due to dynamic loading disappears on integrating expression (37) over the whole length of the beam. Fig. 9
Normalized energy loss versus amplitude

The theoretical loss factor has been evaluated for various configurations and vibration conditions using expressions (49) and (50) and these results as well as the corresponding experimental ones are plotted as solid (——) and dotted lines (...............) in Figs 10 to 15, respectively for comparison. It is observed that both the curves are in good agreement with a maximum variation of 11.7 per cent, which shows the authenticity of the theoretical analysis. Fig. 10
Variation of loss factor with amplitude at Heaviside loading welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 600.6 × 40.2 × 3 mm3

Figures 10 and 11 show that the loss factor decreases with the increase in the initial amplitude of vibration at the free end of the beam model although the increase in the amplitude of vibration raises energy loss due to friction. The strain energy introduced into the system is proportional to the square of the amplitude, as given by expression (47), as such increase in amplitude of excitation increases the input strain energy at a higher rate compared to the energy loss due to friction, which is linearly proportional to the initial amplitude, as given by expression (37), thereby reducing the damping capacity. Fig. 11
Variation of loss factor with amplitude at harmonic loading welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 560.2 × 40.2 × 3 mm3

From Figs 12 and 13, it is concluded that the damping capacity decreases with the increase in thickness. From expression (47), it is evident that the strain energy introduced in to the system is enhanced withthe increase in thickness. Expression (37) reveals that the increase in thickness increases the relative slip, thereby raising the energy loss. Although the energy loss is enhanced with the increase in thickness, the damping capacity is reduced as the dissipation of energy is at a slower rate compared to that of the input strain energy. Fig. 12
Variation of loss factor with thickness at Heaviside loading for welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 600.6 × 40.2 mm2 and amplitude = 0.1 mm Fig. 13
Variation of loss factor with thickness at harmonic loading for welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 600.6 × 40.2 mm2 and amplitude = 0.2 mm

Damping capacity of the layered and welded structures increases with the increase in length, as shown in Figs 14 and 15. With the increase in length, the interface area is increased resulting in greater dissipation of the energy due to friction. Furthermore, with increase in the length of the jointed beam, strain energy introduced into the system is reduced as evident from expression (47). Hence, the overall effect is an increase in the damping capacity of the system. Fig. 14
Variation of loss factor with length at Heaviside loading for jointed and welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 40.2 × 4 mm2 and amplitude = 0.1 mm Fig. 15
Variation of loss factor with length for jointed and welded cantilever beams of dimensions = 40.2 × 3 mm2 and amplitude = 0.2 mm

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The present investigation primarily discusses the various parameters affecting the damping capacity of light-weight aluminium structures that find wide applications in aerospace and automotive industries. The mechanism of interfacial slip damping based on energy approach has been studied vividly in this study. It is found from the experimentally validated numerical results that the damping capacity of welded beams can be improved substantially with use of aforesaid principle. The above design concept can be effectively used in aerospace and automotive industries, which extensively use aluminium materials with welded joints as structural members because of light weight and high damping.
